Award.AwardTitle: A Study of Elements of Teacher Preparation Programs that Interact with Candidates' Characteristics to Support Novice Elementary Teachers to Enact Ambitious Mathematics Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Preparing large numbers of elementary teachers to enact high-quality or ambitious mathematics instruction is a central policy challenge in the U.S. While several studies have tried to identify linkages between features of teacher preparation and student achievement outcomes, few large-scale studies have addressed the relationship between teacher preparation and ambitious mathematics instruction, a more proximal outcome. To meet the need for ambitious mathematics instruction, a more robust research base is needed regarding how to support beginning teachers in enacting such instruction. To that end, this NSF EHR Core Research Level II study will investigate how teacher preparation programs support elementary candidates in developing ambitious mathematics instruction and factors that are associated with how graduates of these programs enact mathematics instruction as first- and second-year teachers. Cultural-historical activity theory (CHAT) in a mixed-methods research design will be applied to examine how elementary candidates' characteristics (i.e., their teaching identity, beliefs, and knowledge with regard to teaching mathematics) interact with their opportunities to learn (OTL) in mathematics methods courses and student teaching experiences to influence their enactment of ambitious mathematics instruction as first- and second-year teachers. The study will also explore how novice teachers' characteristics interact with resources and expectations in their schools to influence their mathematics instruction as teachers of record. The study results will inform the design of university-based teacher preparation programs, including the selection of elementary candidates with particular characteristics, the content of mathematics methods courses, and desirable characteristics of student teaching assignments. This work is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

This study will feature surveys of 150 elementary candidates from a purposively sampled set of six teacher preparation programs in three states during their final year of preparation and their first two years of teaching. The Mathematics Scan (M-Scan) classroom observation instrument will be used to observe these graduates multiple times as they teach mathematics as first- and second-year teachers. M-Scan measures ambitious mathematics instruction by assessing teachers' use of mathematical tasks, discourse, representations, and coherence. In addition, this study will feature interviews with elementary preparation program directors and mathematics methods instructors at each university; and it will feature surveys of teacher educators, practicing teachers, mathematics instructional coaches, and principals who work with the novice teacher study participants. The study's primary outcome is to measure novices' enactment of ambitious mathematics instruction by using the four M-Scan constructs: mathematical tasks, discourse, representations, and coherence. Each construct represents its own dependent variable. Multiple regression will be used to study the main outcome as a function of several independent variables (including individual teacher characteristics, OTL in mathematics methods courses and student teaching, and resources and expectations in novice teachers' schools) and interactions among these variables. All models will include a vector of controls for teacher attributes (e.g., the teacher's ACT/SAT score, selectivity of undergraduate institution, undergraduate grade point average) and school attributes (e.g., student race/ethnicity, student eligibility for free/reduced lunch, school size, urbanicity, curriculum policy, professional development offerings). This project will contribute to building the knowledge base for designing high-quality teacher preparation and induction programs that support elementary candidates and novice teachers with a range of background experiences, beliefs, and knowledge. This includes understanding factors that inhibit or promote the development of ambitious mathematics instruction to ensure that new elementary teachers are able to provide all students with instruction that supports their deep conceptual understanding of mathematical content.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In one main paper for this study, we are drawing on classroom observation and survey data from 76 first-year elementary teachers and 63 second-year elementary teachers who graduated from five teacher education programs to examine how interactions between teacher characteristics and their opportunity-to-learn in mathematics methods courses and student teaching are associated with their enactment of ambitious mathematics instruction as beginning teachers. Such instruction involves helping students develop strong conceptual knowledge in mathematics, acquire procedural fluency, and engage in disciplinary practices (Lampert et al., 2013; Newmann & Associates, 1996). In terms of teacher characteristics, we focus on their mathematical knowledge for teaching, their self-efficacy with regard to teaching mathematics, and their beliefs about teaching and learning mathematics.

In a second main paper, we are drawing on classroom observation and survey data from the same group of teachers to investigate how interactions between teacher characteristics and school resources in elementary mathematics are associated with their enactment of ambitious mathematics instruction as beginning teachers. These resources include principal leadership, mentoring, instructional coaching, professional development, and teacher evaluation. In a third main paper, we are drawing on classroom observation and survey data from the same group of teachers to explore how the degree of similarity between their student teaching/internship schools and the school(s) where they work as beginning teachers are associated with their enactment of ambitious mathematics instruction.

In terms of intellectual merit, our study’s interdisciplinary approach integrated psychological and cognitive components (focused on teachers’ identity, beliefs, and knowledge) and a sociological component (focused on teachers’ school context) in order to understand beginning teachers’ enactment of ambitious mathematics instruction. No mid- or large-scale research studies have used such an approach to measure how teacher preparation and school context shape novices’ mathematics instruction.

Teacher education must be a key facet of efforts to improve the effectiveness of elementary mathematics instruction. Findings from this study enhance our understanding of how teacher education programs help prepare elementary candidates to engage in ambitious math instruction. Such cross-institutional work, with data collected from a relatively large number of candidates, helps in identifying effective strategies, including indicators of courses and field experiences, for preparing novices. This study also allows us to generate empirically-grounded hypotheses to test in larger samples of programs and candidates.

With regard to broader impacts, the math instructional practices of elementary teachers, given the long tail of their potential effects (Chetty et al., 2011), are important levers for improving student outcomes. This project contributes to building the knowledge base for designing high-quality teacher preparation and induction that support elementary candidates with a range of background experiences, beliefs, and knowledge. This includes understanding factors that inhibit or promote the development of ambitious mathematics instruction to ensure that all new elementary teachers are able to provide all students with instruction that supports their deep conceptual understanding of mathematical content.

The results from two of the main papers in this study will inform the design of university-based teacher preparation programs, including the selection of elementary candidates with particular characteristics, the content and pedagogy of mathematics methods courses, and desirable characteristics of student teaching assignments. The results of the third main paper will provide recommendations for how school districts can support beginning elementary teachers in developing and enacting ambitious mathematics instruction through principal leadership, mentoring, instructional coaching, professional development, and teacher evaluation.

In a fourth key paper (in press) from our study, we examined the nature and degree of program coherence in four teacher education programs in our study. Drawing on survey data from elementary candidates, we found significant differences across programs in the degree to which they perceived that their programs had clear visions and high levels of program coherence. Using interview data, we documented ways that program directors, field placement coordinators, and methods instructors worked to support shared visions across courses, between courses and field experiences, and through the criteria used to assess student teachers.

In a fifth key paper (in press), we drew on survey data from elementary teaching candidates to investigate the types of opportunity-to-learn that candidates reported in methods coursework. We also explored how program- and individual-level characteristics explained differences in reported OTL. We reported that across programs, candidates reported more opportunities to approximate practice than to analyze representations of practice or decompose practice. In addition, we found little to no between-program variability among the four programs in our sample.

In a sixth key paper (2020), we drew on classroom observation and interview data from two beginning teachers to investigate how they learned to manage student behavior and enact ambitious instruction. We reported that classroom management is both foundational to ambitious teaching and fundamentally shaped by teachers’ subject-specific instructional practices. We also found that the use of different tools and lesson structures eroded beginning teachers’ management practices and the ambitiousness of their mathematics instruction.
